 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY (EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension
   responsive to IVF.
   .
   ##. Sepsis: Pt was originally admitted after being found down for
   several days complaining of general malaise. After undergoing emergent
   dialysis he was transferred to the floor. On the floor pt was noted to
   be hypotensive. Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with
   + bld cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect
   source to be be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood
   cultures and line culture pending, bld cultures show 4/4 bottles GPC
   with speciation pending.  Line with 4+ GPC on gram stain
   - will f/u blood cultures for speciation
   - continue on broad spectrum with Zosyn/Vanc
   - will consult IR to place temporary line, as renal unable to place [**1-25**]
   scarring
   - transplant surgery will remove HD line today
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses. Pt still
   endorses a lot of back pain and weakness with hip flexion/adduction.
   Given finding of abscesses, and +bld cultures it is possible pt may
   have epidural abscess. Discussed with radiology about using MRI with
   GAD given pt is on dialysis. Per Radiology there may still be a risk
   for NSF. Could image without GAD however would not completely rule out
   abscess. Have consulted Neurology with regards to whether MRI w/o GAD
   coupled with CT scan w/ contast is enough to rule out epidural abscess.
   - f/u final Neurology recs regarding imaging recommendations. After
   speaking with neuro resident and neurorads attg, unlikely to gain
   additional information re: epidural abscess with MRI w/o contrast since
   already have CT spine w/ contrast
   -f/u final read CT spine to potentially d/c neck brace
   - Morphine IV and PO for pain control
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent. Hyperkalemic to 6, s/p kayexelate.
   No EKG changes. Pt received dialysis on admission, Renal is currently
   following pt and he needs dialysis today. Will place line today (IR)
   - continue on HD
   - check [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - continue pt on Sevelamer TID
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to
   mid septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   - f/u digoxin level
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Will continue on home regimen of Levetiracetam,
   Oxcarbazepine. Has not been receiving Levetiracetam because gets with
   dialysis. Neuro concerned about nonepileptic seizures.
   -consider EEG, f/u final neuro recs
   .
   ##. FEN: NPO/aspiration precautions pending speech and swallow eval,
   hyperkalemia-kayexelate and trend K, continue on dialysis
   .
   ##. Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code: presumed full  (must confirm- patient with AMS right now)
   .
   # Communication: HCP :  [**Name (NI) 955**] [**Name (NI) 10135**]
   .
   # Disposition: Likely to floors pending dialysis, removal of lines
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%.
- He was initially admitted for suspected gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from his hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).
- The patient has been experiencing general malaise, back pain, and was found down on the floor.
- He has multiple blood cultures and line culture pending, with blood cultures showing 4/4 bottles positive for GPC.
- The patient is currently in sepsis and the suspected source is the tunneled catheter line.
- He has a history of full-body pain, including back pain, and underwent a cervical-thoracic-lumbar spine CT with contrast, which showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses.
- The patient still endorses back pain and weakness with hip flexion/adduction.
- There is a possibility of an epidural abscess, and an MRI with gadolinium has been discussed due to the patient's dialysis status.
- Neurology has been consulted regarding imaging recommendations, and it was determined that an MRI without contrast would not completely rule out an epidural abscess.
- The patient requires pain control, renal dialysis

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presented with malaise, was found down, and had hyperkalemia. He underwent emergent dialysis and was transferred to the floor. On the floor, he was noted to be hypotensive and developed sepsis. Blood cultures showed growth of gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters. A tunneled catheter line is suspected as the source of infection. The patient has multiple comorbidities including chronic pain, non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 35-40%, and a seizure disorder.

Potential Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis due to a suspected infected tunneled catheter line. Broad-spectrum antibiotics (Zosyn/Vanc) have been started, and blood cultures are pending. The source of infection needs to be addressed, and the line may need to be removed.

2. Epidural Abscess: The patient has back pain and weakness with hip flexion/adduction. A CT scan of the spine showed no gross abscess but revealed lung abscesses. There is a possibility of an epidural abscess, especially given the positive blood cultures. An MRI with gadolinium (GAD) is planned to evaluate for an epidural abscess. Neurology consultation is

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) status post myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%) presenting with malaise, hypotension, and suspected gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line. The patient has been admitted multiple times and is currently in the ICU.

1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis, which is indicated by hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures for GPC. Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old man with GPC bacteremia and sepsis, currently hemodynamically stable. The key findings from the progress note are as follows:

1. GPC bacteremia: The patient is being treated with vancomycin and Zosyn. His white blood cell count (WBC) is rising, and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) will be performed today. The tunneled line will be pulled, and transplant surgery will be conducted.

2. Hypotension: The patient is currently normotensive.

3. Renal failure: The patient will receive temporary hemodialysis after the tunneled line is pulled.

4. Seizures: The patient will be given Keppra IV.

Other issues are noted in the ICU resident's note. The patient requires nutrition support, particularly to enable him to take anti-seizure medications orally. He is currently NPO (nothing by mouth). The patient's lines include a dialysis catheter placed on August 25th, as well as two other lines placed on the same day. Prophylactic measures include subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer prophylaxis not indicated. The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition remains in the ICU. The patient's critical illness necessitates close monitoring and management.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who is dependent on hemodialysis (HD). He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, back pain, and was found down. He was initially treated for suspected gastrointestinal perforation sepsis (GPC) from his HD line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). Blood cultures showed Staphylococcus aureus, and the line was found to have 4+ growth of gram-positive cocci (GPC). The patient is currently being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics (Zosyn/Vanc) and is scheduled for a chest CT to evaluate lung findings. He has a history of chronic pain and weakness with hip flexion/adduction. A C/T/L spine CT showed no gross abscess but did reveal cavitary lung lesions. The patient continues to experience back pain and weakness. There is a concern for possible epidural abscess. Neurology is consulted regarding imaging options, including an MRI with gadolinium contrast, which may pose a risk for nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF). The patient's serum potassium level is elevated at 6.1, and he received kayexelate for hyperkalemia. He is currently on dialysis and needs temporary HD catheter placement

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, coronary artery disease (CAD) with a history of myocardial infarction (MI), non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%, back pain, malaise, and hypotension. He was initially admitted for suspected graft versus host disease (GVHD) sepsis from hemodialysis line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). On the floor, the patient developed hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with positive blood cultures, and pulmonary abscess, indicating sepsis. The suspected source of infection is the tunneled catheter line. The patient has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics (Zosyn/Vanc), and the tunneled line has been removed for culture analysis. A temporary dialysis catheter needs to be placed, and serial blood cultures will be drawn. A chest CT will be performed to evaluate lung findings.

   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY (EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension
   responsive to IVF.
   .
   ##. Sepsis: Pt was originally admitted after being found down for
   several days complaining of general malaise. After undergoing emergent
   dialysis he was transferred to the floor. On the floor pt was noted to
   be hypotensive. Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with
   + bld cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect
   source to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood
   cultures and line culture pending, bld cultures show S aureus.  Line
   with 4+ GPC on gram stain
   - will f/u sensitivities
   - continue on broad spectrum with Zosyn/Vanc. Could dc zosyn.
   - transplant surgery will removed HD line today
   -IR to place temp line
   -no vegetations seen on TTE
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses. Pt still
   endorses a lot of back pain and weakness with hip flexion/adduction.
   Given finding of abscesses, and +bld cultures it is possible pt may
   have epidural abscess. Discussed with radiology about using MRI with
   GAD given pt is on dialysis. Per Radiology there may still be a risk
   for NSF. Could image without GAD however would not completely rule out
   abscess. Have consulted Neurology with regards to whether MRI w/o GAD
   coupled with CT scan w/ contast is enough to rule out epidural abscess.
   - continue to try to clear C spine
   - Morphine IV and PO for pain control

   following pt and he needs dialysis today. Will place line today (IR)

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He was found down and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. The patient was transferred from the floor for suspicion of gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from his hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis, suspected to be caused by the tunneled catheter line. Blood cultures show Staphylococcus aureus, and the line has 4+ GPC on gram stain. Broad-spectrum antibiotics (Zosyn/Vanc) are being continued, and the HD line will be removed today. A temporary line will be placed by interventional radiology (IR).
2. Back Pain: The patient has back pain, and a CT scan with contrast showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses. There is a possibility of an epidural abscess. An MRI with gadolinium is preferred, but there may be a risk for nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) due to the patient's dialysis. A consultation has been made with neurology regarding imaging options to rule out an epidural abscess.
3. ESRD: The patient is currently HD dependent and hyperkalemic

1. GPC Bacteremia: The patient has an ongoing infection caused by Gram-positive cocci bacteria. This can lead to further spread of the infection and organ damage if not effectively treated.

2. Sepsis: The patient is already diagnosed with sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's response to an infection causes injury to its own tissues and organs.

3. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing low blood pressure, which may lead to inadequate blood flow to vital organs such as the brain, heart, and kidneys. This can result in organ dysfunction or failure.

4. Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate impaired kidney function. If left untreated, this can progress to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease, requiring dialysis or kidney transplantation.

5. Diffuse Pain: The patient complains of back pain and diffuse musculoskeletal pain. If the underlying cause is not identified and treated, it may persist or worsen, affecting the patient's quality of life.

He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and a non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%). He was initially admitted for suspected generalized paresis of the cerebellum (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

The patient's current assessment includes the following:

3. Renal failure, end stage (ESRD): The patient is dependent on hemodialysis (HD) for renal function, as indicated by his elevated creatinine levels and history of ESRD.
4. Sepsis without organ dysfunction: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to the presence of S. aureus in his blood cultures, along with hypotension and leukocytosis. The source of sepsis is suspected to be the tunneled catheter line.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) with previous myocardial infarction (MI), non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%), and chronic pain. He presented to the hospital with malaise and was found down, initially hyperkalemic with back pain. The patient underwent emergent dialysis and was transferred to the floor, where he was noted to be hypotensive.

Subsequently, the patient developed respiratory failure, likely secondary to a seizure, and was intubated last night. He also has sepsis without organ dysfunction, suspected to be due to a tunnelled catheter line infection, as indicated by positive blood cultures showing Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is currently on cefepime and nafcillin for sepsis.

The patient also has chronic pain, ESRD, non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, and a history of seizure disorder. He is currently on morphine for pain control, sevelamer for phosphate control, and Digoxin for heart failure management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may progress if the underlying cause, such as the seizure, is not appropriately managed.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis could worsen if the source of infection, suspected to be the tunneled catheter

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) with previous myocardial infarction (MI), non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%), and seizure disorder. The patient presented with generalized malaise and was found down, leading to emergent dialysis and transfer to the floor. On the floor, the patient developed hypotension and was transferred back to the ICU. The patient is currently intubated, sedated, and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has multiple comorbidities, including sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure (acute), seizure (without status epilepticus), pain control (acute pain and chronic pain), renal failure (end-stage), and back pain.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to the presence of fever, leukocytosis, hypotension, and positive blood cultures showing Staphylococcus aureus. The source of infection may be the tunneled catheter line. The patient is currently receiving appropriate antibiotic therapy, and further monitoring of blood cultures and sensitivity is planned.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is secondary to the seizure episode, resulting in hypoxia. He has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. Weaning off the ventilator will be considered when the patient is stable.

3. Back

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%). He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He underwent emergent dialysis and was transferred to the floor, where he developed hypotension. Blood cultures showed Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), and he was diagnosed with sepsis, likely due to a tunneled catheter line. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure, which occurred after a seizure. He also has multiple pulmonary abscesses and cavitated lesions in both lungs, indicating septic emboli and multiple cavitated abscesses from known S. aureus sepsis. The patient has a history of seizures and chronic pain. His renal function is compromised, and he is dependent on dialysis. He also has a small pericardial effusion, multiple bilateral rib fractures, a right non-healed scapular fracture, and multiple bilateral renal cysts. A CT scan of the head showed no hemorrhage, edema, or mass effect. He has a significantly distended gallbladder filled with sludge and at least three rim-calcified gallstones. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and further tests are planned, including a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), lumbar puncture (LP), and MRI. The patient's pain control, seizure management, ESRD, sepsis, respiratory failure, and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy are being addressed.

The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%). He presented with general malaise, hypotension, and was found down. The patient has a history of being on dialysis and was transferred to the ICU for suspected gram-positive cocci sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Sepsis without organ dysfunction: The patient has leukocytosis with positive blood cultures showing Staphylococcus aureus. The source of infection is suspected to be the tunneled catheter line. The patient is on meropenem and nafcillin. Cultures are pending, and the tunneled HD catheter has been removed.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated last night due to hypoxia secondary to seizure. Weaning off the ventilator is planned.
3. Back pain: The patient has full-body pain, specifically back pain. A CT scan of the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses. Pain management with morphine IV and PO is ongoing. An MRI while intubated is being considered.

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY). He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia with back pain. The patient is currently in the ICU for suspected generalized pustular candidiasis (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). He is intubated after experiencing a seizure and has mild respiratory acidosis on pressure support ventilation (PSV). The patient also has several blood cultures and line culture pending, with MSSA identified in the blood cultures. He is on nafcillin (day 6) for MSSA and levo/flagyl (day 2) for suspected aspiration pneumonia. The patient's WBC count continues to trend up, indicating ongoing infection. The assessment and plan include respiratory failure, seizure, pain control, renal failure, sepsis, and back pain.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and barotrauma.
2. Sepsis: The patient has signs of sepsis, including hypotension, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures for MSSA. There is

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presented with malaise, back pain, and was found down. Initial laboratory results showed hyperkalemia. He was transferred to the ICU for suspected sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). The patient has several medical problems including respiratory failure, seizure disorder, chronic pain, renal failure, sepsis, and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure and has purulent secretions. There is a concern about his volume status and the need for a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) tomorrow. The plan is to wean the ventilator and possibly extubate after the TEE.
2. Sepsis: The patient has signs of sepsis including hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). The source of sepsis is suspected to be the tunneled catheter line. Antibiotics have been started, and cultures are pending. Further evaluation with TEE and MRI is needed to guide the treatment.
3. ESRD: The patient is HD dependent and experienced hypotension during dialysis. CVVH is planned, but low blood pressures are a concern. Phosphate control measures are ongoing.
4. Non-ischemic Cardiomyopathy: The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) is 35-40%, and there is severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to mid-septal, anterior, and inferior segments. Monitoring fluid status and continuing on Digoxin are part of the management.
5. Seizure Disorder: The patient had a seizure last night, and no oxcarbazepine was given due to the risk of aspiration. The plan is to continue on home regimen of levetiracetam and oxcarbazepine now that the patient has a nasogastric tube (NGT).
6. R arm swelling and discomfort: An X-ray of the shoulder and consideration of ultrasound to rule out clot are planned.
7. Back Pain: The patient's back pain is being managed with pain control medications, and further evaluation with MRI of the spine is scheduled.
8. Renal Failure: The patient has end-stage renal disease and is dependent on HD. Renal failure management includes CVVH, electrolyte monitoring, and phosphate control.
9. Tunnelled HD catheter removal: The transplant surgery has removed the tunneled HD catheter, and follow-up cultures will be done.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the information provided in the progress note.

   -Got R shoulder Xray with more views to evaluate for trauma

   -ID recs - continue nafcillin and levaquin
      -continue flagyl, increase dose to 500 mg PO Q8

   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY (EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension
   responsive to IVF.
   .
   ##. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with +
   bld cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect
   source to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood
   cultures and line culture pending ALL CX NGTD FOR PAST 48 HOURS, bld
   cultures show MSSA. WBC still elevated, but decreased.  Low grade fever
   to 100.1.
   - On nafcillin (day 5) for MSSA and levo/flagyl (day 2) for ?
   aspiration pna as found down. will need to confirm with ID how long
   course of therapy is, likely will depend on TEE and MRI results
   -will eventually require TEE; discussed yesterday
   -needs LP when more stable to evaluate for seeding to meninges.
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI obtained yesterday - no evidence of epidural abscess
   on prelim read, but will follow up on final read.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath, will continue to follow
   cultures.
   -f/u pending blood cultures, no surveillance cx for today given 48hrs
   NGTD.
   -resent sputum cultures, pending.
   -appreciate ID recs .
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -Unable to wean vent overnight - increased PS without significant
   improvement in CO2.
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses.
   -further shoulder x-rays taken yesterday per radiology recs.
   - so far have been unable to clear C-spine due to altered mental
   status.  Continue C-collar for now, clear when able.
   - Morphine IV and PO for pain control.
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent, was dialyzed 2 days ago, CVVH
   started yesterday, continuing into this morning.  Goal fluid balance
   even.
   - continue pt on Sevelamer TID and phoslo
   .
   # R arm swelling and discomfort: xray shoulder, consider u/s to r/o
   clot
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to
   mid septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Pt with seizure 2 nights ago, likely because did not
   receive oxcarbazepine (b/c no NGT present and felt to be aspiration
   risk by S&S). Will continue on home regimen of Levetiracetam,
   Oxcarbazepine now that patient has NGT.
   -20 min EEG ordered - read pending.
   -continue Keppra, switch back to PO now that pt has NGT.
   -no evidence of septic emboli on head CT.
   -appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # elevated INR:
   -INR of 1.5 - stably elevated for past 2 days, likely [**1-25**] abx and npo.
   .
   #. FEN: tube feeds.  IVF boluses for hypotension. Will continue to
   follow electrolytes and replete as necessary.
   .
   #. Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals, aline, HD temp line
    .
   # Code: FULL
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor to the ICU for suspected gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

The patient has several ongoing medical complications, including respiratory failure, acute seizure without status epilepticus, pain control (acute and chronic pain), ESRD, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and non-ischemic CMY. 

In terms of respiratory failure, the patient was intubated for airway protection after experiencing a seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions overnight. The patient's respiratory acidosis improved slightly after switching to assisted control ventilation (ACV), but he was unable to wean off the ventilator overnight. 

For pain control, the patient is receiving morphine intravenously and orally due to acute and chronic pain. The patient's back pain was noted on admission, and a C-spine was placed given his pain. A CT with contrast showed no gross abscess but revealed lung abscess

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) after myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for suspicion of Gram-positive cocci sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure, and there is evidence of lung abscesses on imaging. He also experienced a seizure and is being treated with antiepileptic drugs. The patient has ESRD and is HD dependent, with ongoing fluid balance concerns. There are other comorbidities mentioned in the note, including chronic pain, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and an elevated INR.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures suggest ongoing sepsis, likely originating from the tunneled catheter line. Cultures are pending, and the patient is receiving appropriate antibiotic therapy.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure requires ongoing ventilatory support. Copious purulent secretions overnight indicate an ongoing infection or inflammation.

   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY (EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension
   responsive to IVF.
   .
   ##. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with +
   bld cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect
   source to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood
   cultures and line culture pending ALL CX NGTD FOR PAST 48 HOURS, bld
   cultures show MSSA. WBC still elevated, but decreased.  Low grade fever
   to 100.1.
   - On nafcillin (day 5) for MSSA and levo/flagyl (day 2) for ?
   aspiration pna as found down. will need to confirm with ID how long
   course of therapy is, likely will depend on TEE and MRI results
   -will require TEE; discussed yesterday
   -needs LP to evaluate for seeding to meninges, as per ID; but has been
   on antibiotics for days now, wondering if it will change management.
   Will discuss further with ID
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI obtained yesterday - no evidence of epidural abscess
   on prelim read, but will follow up on final read.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath, will continue to follow
   cultures.
   -f/u pending blood cultures, no surveillance cx for today given 48hrs
   NGTD.
   -resent sputum cultures, pending.
   -appreciate ID recs .
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -Unable to wean vent overnight - increased PS without significant
   improvement in CO2.
   -Will work more to wean after TEE
   -Will do therapeutic bronch /cultures today to help with purulent
   secretions
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses.
   - shoulder Xrays negative for fracture.
   - so far have been unable to clear C-spine due to altered mental
   status.  Continue C-collar for now, clear when able.
   - Fentanyl boluses for pain control.
   - f/u final read of MRI of back to r/o epidural abscess
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent, was dialyzed 2 days ago, CVVH
   started yesterday, continuing into this morning.  Goal fluid balance
   even.
   - continue pt on Sevelamer TID and phoslo
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to
   mid septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Pt with seizure 2 nights ago, likely because did not
   receive oxcarbazepine (b/c no NGT present and felt to be aspiration
   risk by S&S). Will continue on home regimen of Levetiracetam,
   Oxcarbazepine now that patient has NGT.
   -20 min EEG ordered - read pending.
   -continue Keppra, switch back to PO now that pt has NGT.
   -no evidence of septic emboli on head CT.
   -appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # elevated INR:
   -INR of 1.5 - stably elevated for past 2 days, likely [**1-25**] abx and npo.
   .
   #. FEN: tube feeds.  IVF boluses for hypotension. Will continue to
   follow electrolytes and replete as necessary.
   .
   #. Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   # Access: peripherals, aline, HD temp line
    .
   # Code: FULL

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, hyperkalemia, and back pain. The patient was initially suspected to have sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). He is currently intubated for airway protection after experiencing a seizure. The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, seizure, pain control, renal failure, and sepsis.

Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with positive blood cultures, and pulmonary abscess. The suspected source of infection is the tunneled catheter line. He is currently receiving antibiotics for MSSA and Flagyl for aspiration pneumonia.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated for airway protection after the seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions and is awaiting a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). There is mild respiratory acidosis on pressure support ventilation (PSV), and he has been switched to assist-control (AC) ventilation overnight with slight improvement

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%.
- The patient presented with a three-day history of malaise, found down and initially hyperkalemic with back pain.
- He was transferred from the floor for suspicion of gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).
- The patient has been intubated for airway protection after a seizure.
- He has copious purulent secretions overnight and is awaiting a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).
- The patient is also experiencing back pain, with a C-spine immobilized due to pain and an upcoming MRI to rule out an epidural abscess.
- He is currently on nafcillin and levoquin for MSSA and flagyl for aspiration pneumonia.
- The patient has ESRD and is HD dependent, with CVVH started yesterday.
- His non-ischemic CMY is being monitored with continued use of digoxin.
- The patient had a seizure two nights ago and will continue on levetiracetam and oxcarbazepine.
- There is an elevated INR of 1

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with a three-day history of malaise, found down and initially hyperkalemic, with back pain. The patient was transferred from the floor for suspicion of gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

24-hour Events:
- Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) performed.
- Right shoulder X-ray with more views to evaluate for trauma.
- Continuous Venous Hemodialfiltration (CVVH) started and continued overnight.
- Infectious Disease (ID) recommendations: continue nafcillin and levoquin.
- Flagyl dose increased to 500 mg orally every eight hours.
- Lumbar puncture (LP) and Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) should be done within the next day or two.
- Renal recommendations: CVVH, start Epo three times a week.
- MRI discussed with radiology - should follow up on the final neurorad read tomorrow. Preliminary read: no signs of cord compression, significant degenerative changes from C3 to C7, grossly no sign of acute process

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presents with malaise, back pain, and was initially found to be hyperkalemic. The patient was transferred from the floor for suspicion of gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Sepsis/Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia: The patient is still on a small amount of norepinephrine in the setting of intubation/sedation. He is afebrile, and the tunneled line has been pulled. He will continue on nafcillin. A plan for transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) has been made before attempting extubation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient continues to have purulent secretions. He is on meropenem. He will await TEE before attempting extubation. Bronchoscopy will also be performed today.
3. Back/Shoulder Pain: Awaiting read of shoulder films. The patient cannot clear c-spine definitively until a better clinical exam post-extubation.
4. ESRD: CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration).

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of HD dependent ESRD, CAD post-myocardial infarction, and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy. He presented with malaise, found down and initially hyperkalemic, and had back pain. The patient was transferred from the floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension responsive to IV fluids.

24-hour events include bronchoscopy, MRI, LP, PICC line placement, and various interventions to manage respiratory failure, pain, and sepsis. The patient's condition remains unstable with ongoing hypotension, respiratory distress, and elevated INR. He is currently on multiple medications including fentanyl, norepinephrine, KCl, calcium gluconate, and midazolam.

The patient has several lab abnormalities including leukocytosis, elevated lactate, and renal dysfunction. Cultures are pending to identify the source of infection. The patient's pain, nutrition, and electrolyte imbalances require ongoing monitoring and management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, hypoglycemia, and leukocytosis suggest ongoing sepsis, likely secondary to the tunneled HD catheter line. Blood cultures show MSSA, and antibiotics have been initiated.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to airway protection and ongoing respiratory distress

- The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, hypoglycemia, and hyperkalemia and was found down. He is currently on mechanical ventilation in the ICU.
- The patient has multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, seizure, pain control, renal failure, and others.
- The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for suspected MSSA and GPC sepsis from the HD line. Blood cultures are pending.
- He underwent a bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) performed, which showed no microorganisms seen on gram stain.
- The patient's back pain was noted on admission, and a C-spine CT with contrast showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses. Shoulder X-rays were negative for fracture.
- The patient's renal function is being closely monitored, as he is HD dependent and undergoing CVVH.
- The patient also has a history of non-ischemic CMY with severe left ventricular hypokinesis/near akinesis.
- He experienced a seizure two nights ago, and his antiepileptic drug regimen has been adjusted.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He was admitted with malaise, found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He is suspected to have gastrointestinal perforation sepsis from his hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

The patient underwent various procedures including bronchoscopy, transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which showed no significant findings except for possible osteomyelitis. He had a seizure and required intubation for airway protection. He is currently on multiple medications including antibiotics, sedatives, analgesics, and cardiac medications.

The patient's vital signs are unstable, and he requires assistance for breathing. His blood cultures show methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), and he has been started on nafcillin. He also has elevated white blood cell count, low-grade fever, and respiratory acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has signs of sepsis including hypotension, leukocytosis with elevated white blood cell count, and positive blood cultures. The suspected source of infection is the tunnelled cath

   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY (EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension
   responsive to IVF.
   .
   ##. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with +
   bld cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect
   source to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood
   cultures and line culture pending, but all negative for past several
   days, bld cultures show MSSA. WBC still elevated, but decreased.  Low
   grade fever to 100.1 yesterday, none overnight.
   - On nafcillin (day 6) for MSSA and levo/flagyl (day 3) for ?
   aspiration pna as found down. will need to confirm with ID how long
   course of therapy is, likely will depend on TEE results
   -TTE not done, will need to wait until collar removed.
   -LP performed yesterday
 counts normal, cultures pending.  Results
   obviously limited given multiple days of abx treatment.
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI obtained yesterday
 cannot rule out atypical osteo,
   but no epidural seen.  Also recommend followup of enlarged thyroid
   will defer until more stable.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath, will continue to follow
   cultures.
   -f/u pending blood cultures, no positive cultures so far over past 6
   days.
   -resent sputum cultures, pending.
   -ID recs this morning:  continue nafcillin, follow up cultures from
   sacral swab
 add HSV/VZV to CSF culture.  Would not recommend empiric
   antiviral treatment at this point.  Plan to switch to cefazolin when on
   regular dialysis, renal function more stable.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -Unable to wean vent overnight - increased PS without significant
   improvement in CO2.
   -Will work more to wean after TEE
   -Bronch performed yesterday, BAL sent.
 Gram Stain:  >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.
         NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN.
   .
   #Hypotension: currently on Levophed, 0.1.  Likely secondary to
   persistent infection, lung abscesses.  Could also be due to cardiac
   valvular seeding, unable to perform TEE to this point.  (TTE negative
   for vegetations).
   - wean levophed as tolerated
 unable to wean yesterday.
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses.
   - shoulder Xrays negative for fracture.
   - so far have been unable to clear C-spine due to altered mental
   status.  Continue C-collar for now, clear when able. Will lighten
   sedation today and try to do a better exam if able.
   - Fentanyl boluses for pain control
 required increased fentanyl and
   Versed yesterday for pain, discomfort.
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent, was dialyzed 2 days ago, CVVH
   started 2 days ago, continuing.
   - continue pt on Sevelamer TID and phoslo
   -renal following.
   -we will remember to change his keppra and allopurinol back to home
   doses once off CVVH and back on HD
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesisof the basal to mid
   septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Pt with seizure 2 nights ago, likely because did not
   receive oxcarbazepine (b/c no NGT present and felt to be aspiration
   risk by S&S). Will continue on home regimen of Levetiracetam,
   Oxcarbazepine now that patient has NGT.
   -still awaiting final read on EEG.
   -continue Keppra, switch back to PO now that pt has NGT.  Dosing
   adjusted now for CVVH.
   -no evidence of septic emboli on head CT.
   -appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # elevated INR:
   -INR of 1.5 - stably elevated for past 2 days, likely [**1-25**] abx and npo.
   .
   #. FEN: tube feeds.  IVF boluses for hypotension. Will continue to
   follow electrolytes and replete as necessary.

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of HD-dependent ESRD, CAD post MI, non-ischemic CMY (ejection fraction 35-40%) presenting with a 3-day history of malaise, found down, initially hyperkalemic, and experiencing back pain. He was transferred from the floor for suspicion of GPC sepsis from HD line and hypotension responsive to IVF.

The patient underwent several procedures including bronchoscopy, which showed no evidence of abscesses or emboli to the brain on head CT, non-contrast MRI obtained yesterday cannot rule out atypical osteomyelitis, but no epidural seen. Transplant surgery removed tunneled HD catheter, and blood cultures are pending.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure ranging from 130/61mmHg to 148/92mmHg, heart rate between 86-126 bpm, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is intubated, sedated, and minimally responsive with coarse inspiratory rales bilaterally, regular heart rhythm, and 1+ pedal edema.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count, decreased hemoglobin levels, elevated platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, and abnormal electrolyte levels including hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. Other

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of hemodialysis-dependent end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia and back pain. He was transferred from the floor for suspicion of gastrointestinal perforation sepsis (GPC) from the hemodialysis line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

The patient underwent various procedures including a bronchoscopy, which showed purulent secretions but no microorganisms. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) could not be performed due to the need to remove the collar before the procedure. An MRI of the spine was also done, showing no evidence of epidural abscess but cannot rule out atypical osteomyelitis. A lumbar puncture was performed with normal counts and cultures pending.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.3 degrees Celsius (101 degrees Fahrenheit), blood pressure ranging from 130/61 mmHg to 148/92 mmHg, heart rate between 86 and 126 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume

Summary:
This is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, hypoglycemia, hyperkalemia, back pain, and was found down. He was initially suspected to have gram-positive cocci sepsis from the hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). The patient is currently in the ICU for further management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis, likely due to a suspected tunnelled catheter line infection. Blood cultures show methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), and the patient is being treated with nafcillin and levofloxacin. Line cultures are pending.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated for airway protection after a seizure and is experiencing copious purulent secretions. The patient is awaiting a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) and bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) to identify the causative organism.
3. Back Pain: The patient has back pain, which may be due to a lung abscess seen on imaging. The patient's shoulder X

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with malaise, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. He was found down and suspected to have sepsis from his hemodialysis (HD) line. The patient is currently in the ICU and is experiencing respiratory failure, MSSA bacteremia, and ESRD.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis/MSSA Bacteremia: The patient is already on nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia, but continuous monitoring and antibiotic therapy will be necessary to control the infection and prevent further complications.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his critical condition and prolonged mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring of his respiratory status, daily weaning trials, and infection control measures will be crucial to improve his chances of extubation.
3. ESRD: The patient's ESRD requires ongoing hemodialysis support. Frequent monitoring of electrolyte levels and fluid balance will be necessary to manage his renal replacement therapy effectively.
4. Other ICU Issues: The patient has multiple other issues mentioned in the ICU resident note, which need to be addressed appropriately, including nutrition, glycemic control, line management, and prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He was admitted to the ICU due to suspected gram-positive cocci (GPC) sepsis from his hemodialysis (HD) line and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF).

The patient has multiple medical complications and conditions, including MSSA bacteremia, respiratory failure, and ESRD. He is currently receiving treatment for these conditions, such as antibiotics (nafcillin), respiratory support, and continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

The patient's vital signs show fever, low blood pressure, and an elevated heart rate. His oxygen saturation is within normal limits, but his respiratory rate is slightly increased. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The physical examination reveals right and left lower extremity edema, warm skin, and neurologic impairment with unresponsiveness and absence of movement or tone.

Laboratory results indicate anemia, elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine, low sodium, low potassium, and elevated lactate levels. Other lab values are within normal ranges.

The patient has a history of malaise, back pain, and a previous myocardial infarction. Imaging studies, including an MRI of the spine, have shown no evidence of infection.

 add HSV/VZV to CSF culture.  Would not recommend empiric

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) with a previous myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presents with malaise, hypotension, hypoglycemia, and leukocytosis, indicating sepsis. He has MSSA sepsis and is currently being treated with nafcillin and levofloxacin. The patient also has lung abscesses, which may be the source of infection. Blood cultures are pending, and the tunnelled catheter line is suspected as the possible source of infection. 

The patient is intubated for airway protection after experiencing a seizure. He has copious purulent secretions and is on mechanical ventilation. TEE (transesophageal echocardiogram) is planned to assess for cardiac valvular seeding, but it has not been performed yet due to the patient's altered mental status. 

The patient's back pain is ongoing, and he underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast, which showed no gross abscess but did reveal lung abscesses. He is wearing a cervical collar, and attempts to clear it have been unsuccessful due to his altered mental status. 

The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVH) and is HD dependent.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia with back pain. The patient has been diagnosed with MSSA sepsis and is currently in the ICU for multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis without organ dysfunction: The patient has MSSA sepsis, which is currently being treated with nafcillin. Cultures are pending, and the source of infection may be a tunneled hemodialysis catheter line.
2. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS): The patient was intubated for airway protection after a seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions and is on pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV) with mild respiratory acidosis. A tracheal examination (TEE) is planned.
3. Ileus: The patient had feculent material from the nasogastric tube (NGT) overnight. The NGT has been placed on suction, and there are small residuals. Surgery has been consulted, and imaging studies are reassuring, ruling out ileus or obstruction.
4. Hypotension: The patient is on levophed due to persistent infection and lung abscess

   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for MSSA sepsis.
   .
   #. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with + bld
   cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect source
   to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood cultures
   and line culture pending, but all negative for past several days, bld
   cultures show MSSA. WBC still elevated, but decreased since yesterday,
   no fevers in 24 hours.
   - On nafcillin (day 7) for MSSA, Levaquin and Flagyl discontinued
   today.
   -initially was considering getting TEE when c spine cleared but now in
   the setting of pulm abscess (req a long course of abx) and TTE neg for
   vegetations (suggesting no vegetations large enough to require
   intervention) it is not clear that we will need a TEE.
   -LP performed 2d ago
 counts normal, cultures pending.  Results
   obviously limited given multiple days of abx treatment.
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI showed no evidence for epidural abscess.  Also
   recommend followup of enlarged thyroid
 will defer until more stable.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath, will continue to follow
   cultures.
   -f/u pending blood cultures, no positive blood cultures since [**8-25**].
   -sputum cx pos for MSSA from [**8-30**], no other organisms identified, other
   sputum cx still pending
   -pt found to have sacral pustules versus vesicles which were sent for
   HSV/VZV PCR. Will follow these, not treating empirically ---Plan to
   switch to cefazolin when on regular dialysis, renal function more
   stable
   -greatly appreciate ID recs
   .
   #? Ileus: Pt had feculent material from NGT  overnight. NGT placed on
   suction and has not had feculent material in past few hours. Surgery
   consulted and KUB and CT abd have initial reads which are reassuring s
   ileus or obstruction
   -NGT now draining bilious fluid, small residuals.
   -greatly appreciate surgery input
   -will restart tube feeds as studies reassuring
   -keppra currently IV but will switch back to PO once tolerating tube
   feeds for several hours
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -placed on psv trial this am
   -continue intubation while mental status remains poor and secretions
   remain.
   -continue to assess mental status daily with sedation wean.
   -SBT today.
   .
   #Hypotension: Likely secondary to persistent infection, lung abscesses.

   .

   - Fentanyl boluses for pain control
 required increased fentanyl and

   - will continue to monitor fluid status

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. The patient was transferred from the floor for MSSA sepsis. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis due to MSSA infection. The source of infection is suspected to be the tunneled catheter line. He is receiving nafcillin for MSSA, and other antibiotics have been discontinued.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated for airway protection after a seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions overnight. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is pending to assess for vegetations. The patient is currently on pressure support ventilation (PSV), and his respiratory acidosis has improved with assisted ventilation.

3. Ileus: The patient had feculent material from the nasogastric tube (NGT) overnight, which indicates a possible ileus. The NGT has been placed on suction, and bilious fluid is now draining, suggesting a partial resolution of the ileus.

4. Back Pain: The patient has full-body pain and

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with malaise, back pain, and hyperkalemia. He was found down and initially suspected to have gonococcal sepsis from his hemodialysis (HD) line. He was transferred to the ICU for suspected sepsis and hypotension responsive to intravenous fluids (IVF). The patient has multiple comorbidities, including ESRD, CAD, and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 35-40%. He is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure caused by MSSA bacteremia and lung abscesses. The patient is also experiencing ileus, as evidenced by the presence of bilious material from the nasogastric tube (NGT).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis/MSSA bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis. It is important to continue nafcillin treatment and monitor for signs of clinical improvement, such as fever curve and white blood cell count.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has respiratory failure due to MSSA bacteremia and lung abscesses. BAL with MSSA has been done, and nafcillin therapy is being continued. RSBI is good, and a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT)

He has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, ileus, hypotension, back pain, ESRD, and seizure disorder.

1. Sepsis: The patient's current condition suggests ongoing infection, which could lead to sepsis. Monitoring for signs of infection and maintaining appropriate antibiotic treatment is crucial.

3. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension may be attributed to persistent infection and lung abscesses. Close monitoring of blood pressure and hemodynamic stability is essential. Pressors may be required to maintain adequate blood pressure.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presented with malaise, hyperkalemia, and back pain. He was initially diagnosed with sepsis and MSSA bacteremia and was started on antibiotics. The patient has respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation. He also has impaired skin integrity, altered nutrition, pain control, renal failure, and seizures.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to MSSA bacteremia and pneumonia. Complications may include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), worsening hypoxia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis/MSSA Bacteremia: The patient has sepsis caused by MSSA bacteremia. Complications may include septic shock, multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
3. ESRD: The patient has end-stage renal disease and is dependent on hemodialysis (HD). Complications may include hyperkalemia, fluid overload, and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Ileus: The patient has an ileus, which may lead to complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, and infection.
5. Seizures: The patient has experienced seizures, which may recur and lead to complications such as status

   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for MSSA sepsis.
   .
   #. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with + bld
   cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect source
   to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood cultures
   and line culture pending, but all negative for past several days, bld
   cultures show MSSA. WBC still elevated, but decreased since yesterday,
   no fevers in 72 hours.
   - On nafcillin (day 9) for MSSA
   -initially was considering getting TEE when c spine cleared but now in
   the setting of pulm abscess (req a long course of abx) and TTE neg for
   vegetations (suggesting no vegetations large enough torequire
   intervention) it is not clear that we will need a TEE as course of abx
   will be 6 weeks regardless (though given the burden of abscesses in the
   lungs it would be interesting to get a look at tricuspid and pulmonic
   valves).
   -Plan to switch to cefazolin when on regular dialysis, renal function
   more stable
   -greatly appreciate ID recs
   -LP performed, cultures pending.  Results obviously limited given
   multiple days of abx treatment.
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI showed no evidence for epidural abscess.  Also
   recommend followup of enlarged thyroid
 will defer until more stable.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath on [**8-26**], tip grew MSSA.
   -f/u pending blood cultures, no positive blood cultures since [**8-25**].
   -sputum cx pos for MSSA from [**8-30**] and [**8-31**]
   -pt found to have sacral pustules versus vesicles which were sent for
   HSV/VZV PCR. Will follow these, not treating empirically
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -extubated
   .
   #Hypotension: Likely secondary to persistent infection, lung abscesses.
   Now also low pressures [**1-25**] cvvh. Restarted pressors at 3am
   -will attempt to wean pressors prn
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses. Had episode of
   tachypnea/presumed pain yesterday and gave bolus of fentanyl.
   - so far have been unable to clear C-spine due to altered mental
   status.  Continue C-collar for now, clear when able.
   - Fentanyl patch and fentanyl boluses for pain control
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent, now on CVVH.
   - continue pt on Sevelamer TID and phoslo and epo
   -renal following.
   -we will remember to change his keppra and allopurinol back to home
   doses once off CVVH and back on HD; CVVH clotted off, will discuss with
   renal
   .
   #? Ileus: Pt had feculent material from NGT overnight. NGT placed on
   suction and has not had feculent material in past few hours. Surgery
   consulted and KUB and CT abd have initial reads which are reassuring s
   ileus or obstruction
   -seems to have resolved
   -tolerating tube feeds
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to
   mid septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Pt with seizure several nights ago, in setting of HD
   and on oxcarbezepine ([**1-25**] no ngt at that time). Will continue on home
   regimen of Levetiracetam, Oxcarbazepine now that patient has NGT.
   -continue Keppra, switch back to PO now that pt has NGT.  Dosing
   adjusted now for CVVH.
   -no evidence of septic emboli on head CT.
   -appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # elevated INR:
   -INR of 1.5 - stably elevated for several days, likely [**1-25**] abx and npo.
   -will trend
   .
   # ? renal mass: per CT read: 3. Right renal high denity region (2, 30)
   in a setting of end-stage renal disease, likely represents a hyperdense
   cyst, although underlying tumor cannot
   be ruled out. Close followup with ultrasound is recommended. Two left
   renal cysts as detailed above, (2, 29), (2, 21).
   -will need f/u as outpt
   .
   #. FEN: tube feeds on. Needs S+S eval.  IVF boluses for hypotension.
   Will continue to follow electrolytes and replete as necessary.  Renal
   also following with CVVH protocol- will have to be sure that he can
   still get it now that filter clotted off.

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%). He presented with malaise, hypoglycemia, and back pain, and was found to have a pulmonary abscess, MSSA sepsis, and elevated white blood cell count. He has been intubated for airway protection and is currently on invasive ventilation. He has undergone several procedures and treatments, including dialysis, administration of antibiotics, and placement of a tunneled hemodialysis catheter. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension, respiratory failure, impaired skin integrity, seizure disorder, pain control issues, and potential complications related to his ESRD.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's current presentation suggests ongoing infection, evidenced by persistent blood cultures showing MSSA. There is a concern for the source of infection, which may be the tunneled catheter line. The patient is already on nafcillin and will be switched to cefazolin once on regular dialysis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated due to a seizure and has been experiencing copious purulent secretions. He is currently extubated but may require reintubation if his respiratory status deteriorates.
3. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure is likely secondary to

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia with back pain. The patient was transferred from the floor for MSSA sepsis. He has several comorbidities, including respiratory failure, seizure, hypotension, pain control, ESRD, and possible ileus.

The patient's recent history includes being intubated for airway protection after a seizure. He has copious purulent secretions overnight and is awaiting a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). The patient was extubated successfully. He has a history of back pain and was placed on a cervical spine (C-spine) brace due to pain. A CT scan of the C/T/L spine showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses. The patient had an episode of tachypnea/presumed pain yesterday and received a bolus of fentanyl.

The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and has been HD-dependent. He is also taking Sevelamer TID and phoslo and epo for renal follow-up. The patient had feculent material from a nasogastric tube (NGT) overnight, which was suctioned. Surgery consulted and KUB and CT abdomen showed initial reads which are reassuring

The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who presented with malaise, back pain, and was found down. He was initially hyperkalemic and had elevated white blood cell count (WBC). Blood cultures showed MSSA. The patient was transferred from the floor for MSSA sepsis. He is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS), seizure without status epilepticus, hypotension (not shock), pain control (acute pain, chronic pain), renal failure, end stage (ESRD), and sepsis without organ dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis, with suspected source being the tunnelled catheter line. Blood cultures are pending, but all negative for the past several days. The patient is on nafcillin for MSSA.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection after a seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions overnight. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is planned to evaluate for vegetations.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to persistent infection and lung abscesses. Pressors were restarted at 3 am, and the patient will attempt to wean them as needed.
4. Back Pain: The patient had full

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI).
- The patient presented with malaise, hyperkalemia, and back pain and was initially found down.
- He was transferred from the floor with MSSA sepsis and bacteremia.
- His blood pressure improved after adjusting cuff pressures and removing an arterial line.
- The patient was extubated yesterday and is currently comfortable without any complaints of pain.
- He has been extubated and is breathing with the assistance of a nasal cannula.
- He is receiving nutrition through NovaSource Renal (Full) at 30 mL/hour.
- His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate between 108-110 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 95/61 mmHg to 143/69 mmHg, respiratory rate between 29-37 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 90%.
- The patient has a history of ESRD and is dependent on hemodialysis.
- He also has a history of CAD and previous myocardial infarction.
- The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased potassium levels, and abnormal liver function tests.
- His microbiology results indicate MSSA in the bronchoalveolar lavage.
- The patient
