   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for MSSA sepsis.
   .
   #. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with + bld
   cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect source
   to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood cultures
   and line culture pending, but all negative for past several days, bld
   cultures show MSSA. WBC still elevated, but decreased since yesterday,
   no fevers in 72 hours.
   - On nafcillin (day 9) for MSSA
   -initially was considering getting TEE when c spine cleared but now in
   the setting of pulm abscess (req a long course of abx) and TTE neg for
   vegetations (suggesting no vegetations large enough to require
   intervention) it is not clear that we will need a TEE as course of abx
   will be 6 weeks regardless (though given the burden of abscesses in the
   lungs it would be interesting to get a look at tricuspid and pulmonic
   valves).
   -Plan to switch to cefazolin when on regular dialysis, renal function
   more stable
   -greatly appreciate ID recs
   -LP performed, cultures pending.  Results obviously limited given
   multiple days of abx treatment.
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI showed no evidence for epidural abscess.  Also
   recommend followup of enlarged thyroid
 will defer until more stable.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath on [**8-26**], tip grew MSSA.
   -f/u pending blood cultures, no positive blood cultures since [**8-25**].
   -sputum cx pos for MSSA from [**8-30**] and [**8-31**]
   -pt found to have sacral pustules versus vesicles which were sent for
   HSV/VZV PCR. Will follow these, not treating empirically
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -extubated
   .
   #Hypotension: Likely secondary to persistent infection, lung abscesses.
   Now also low pressures [**1-25**] cvvh. Restarted pressors at 3am
   -will attempt to wean pressors prn
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses. Had episode of
   tachypnea/presumed pain yesterday and gave bolus of fentanyl.
   - so far have been unable to clear C-spine due to altered mental
   status.  Continue C-collar for now, clear when able.
   - Fentanyl patch and fentanyl boluses for pain control
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent, now on CVVH.
   - continue pt on Sevelamer TID and phoslo and epo
   -renal following.
   -we will remember to change his keppra and allopurinol back to home
   doses once off CVVH and back on HD; CVVH clotted off, will discuss with
   renal
   .
   #? Ileus: Pt had feculent material from NGT overnight. NGT placed on
   suction and has not had feculent material in past few hours. Surgery
   consulted and KUB and CT abd have initial reads which are reassuring s
   ileus or obstruction
   -seems to have resolved
   -tolerating tube feeds
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to
   mid septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Pt with seizure several nights ago, in setting of HD
   and on oxcarbezepine ([**1-25**] no ngt at that time). Will continue on home
   regimen of Levetiracetam, Oxcarbazepine now that patient has NGT.
   -continue Keppra, switch back to PO now that pt has NGT.  Dosing
   adjusted now for CVVH.
   -no evidence of septic emboli on head CT.
   -appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # elevated INR:
   -INR of 1.5 - stably elevated for several days, likely [**1-25**] abx and npo.
   -will trend
   .
   # ? renal mass: per CT read: 3. Right renal high denity region (2, 30)
   in a setting of end-stage renal disease, likely represents a hyperdense
   cyst, although underlying tumor cannot
   be ruled out. Close followup with ultrasound is recommended. Two left
   renal cysts as detailed above, (2, 29), (2, 21).
   -will need f/u as outpt
   .
   #. FEN: tube feeds on. Needs S+S eval.  IVF boluses for hypotension.
   Will continue to follow electrolytes and replete as necessary.  Renal
   also following with CVVH protocol- will have to be sure that he can
   still get it now that filter clotted off.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of hemodialysis dependent end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for MSSA sepsis. In the ICU, he developed several medical complications including respiratory failure, hypotension, impaired skin integrity, altered mental status, and pain control issues. The patient underwent multiple interventions and tests, including dialysis, antibiotic therapy, imaging studies, and procedures to address the various complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient was diagnosed with MSSA sepsis, which required prompt antibiotic treatment. There is suspicion that the tunneled catheter line might be the source of infection. Blood cultures showed MSSA, and the patient is currently on nafcillin.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient required intubation for airway protection after experiencing a seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions and is awaiting further evaluation with a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).

3. Hypotension: The patient's persistent infection and lung abscesses likely contribute to his hypotension. Pressors were restarted at 3 AM, and

   Assessment and Plan: This is a 59 y.o. Male with HD dependent ESRD, CAD
   s/p MI, non-ischemic CMY EF 35-40%) p/w 3 day h.o. malaise, found down
   and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. Pt transferred from the
   floor for MSSA sepsis.
   .
   #. Sepsis: Given the hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis with + bld
   cultures, pulmonary abscess pt is currently in sepsis. Suspect source
   to be tunnelled catheter line. Pt currently has several blood cultures
   and line culture pending, but no recent positive cultures, earlier
   cultures grew MSSA.  Had been afebrile for past 2 days, but with low
   grade temps overnight.
   -WBC decreased past 2 days
 leukocytosis now resolved.
   - On nafcillin (day 10) for MSSA
   - continue to follow cultures
 last positive blood culture [**8-25**], last
   resp. culture [**8-31**]
 both MSSA.
   -initially was considering getting TEE when c spine cleared but now in
   the setting of pulm abscess (req a long course of abx) and TTE neg for
   vegetations (suggesting no vegetations large enough to require
   intervention) it is not clear that we will need a TEE as course of abx
   will be 6 weeks regardless (though given the burden of abscesses in the
   lungs it would be interesting to get a look at tricuspid and pulmonic
   valves).
   -Plan to switch to cefazolin when on regular dialysis, renal function
   more stable.
   - appreciate ID recs
 will continue to follow.
   -LP performed, Gram stain negative, cultures pending.  Results
   obviously limited given multiple days of abx treatment.
   -no evidence of abscesses/emboli to brain on head CT.
   -non-contrast MRI showed no evidence for epidural abscess.  Also
   recommend followup of enlarged thyroid
 will defer until more stable.
   -transplant surgery removed tunneled HD cath on [**8-26**], tip grew MSSA.
   -pt found to have sacral pustules versus vesicles which were sent for
   HSV/VZV PCR. Will follow these, not treating empirically
   #Anemia
 HCT 21.8 today, down from 25.  No evidence of active bleed.
   -re-check hematocrit today, transfuse if necessary.
   -continue to follow.
   -active T & S
   .
   # Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection after seizure.
   Continuing to have copious purulent secretions overnight. Also awaiting
   TEE. Mild respiratory acidosis on PSV, switched to AC overnight with
   slight improvement.
   -extubated
   .
   #Hypotension: Likely secondary to persistent infection, lung abscesses.
   Now off pressors.
   -hypotensive episode overnight, responded to fluid bolus 250 cc.
   .
   ##. Back Pain: Pt on admission was noted to have full body pain and
   specifically back pain. In the [**Name (NI) **] pt was placed on a C-spine given his
   pain and underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with contrast which showed no gross
   abscess but did show the aforementioned lung abscesses. Had episode of
   tachypnea/presumed pain yesterday and gave bolus of fentanyl.
   - so far have been unable to clear C-spine due to altered mental
   status.  Continue C-collar for now, clear when able.
   - Fentanyl patch and fentanyl boluses for pain control
   .
   ##. ESRD: Pt currently HD dependent, was on CVVH, now on HD
 2 liters
   negative yesterday.
   - continue phoslo and epo, sevalemer stopped yesterday as per renal
   recs.
   -renal following.
   -will check to make sure drug doses are appropriate now that on HD and
   not CVVH.
   .
   #? Ileus: Feculent material from NGT several days ago
 now resolved.
   Surgery saw and signed off, CT abd negative.
   -seems to have resolved
   -tolerating tube feeds
   .
   ##. Non-Ichemic CMY: Pt's prior Echo in [**2114**] shows EF of 35-40% as well
   as left ventricular severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to
   mid septal, anterior and inferior segments.
   - will continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue on Digoxin
   .
   ##. Seizure d.o.: Pt with seizure several nights ago, in setting of HD
   and on oxcarbezepine ([**1-25**] no ngt at that time). Will continue on home
   regimen of Levetiracetam, Oxcarbazepine now that patient has NGT.
   -continue meds PO.
   -no evidence of septic emboli on head CT.
   -appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # elevated INR:
   -INR of 1.4- has been stable.
   -will trend
   .
   # ? renal mass: per CT read: 3. Right renal high denity region (2, 30)
   in a setting of end-stage renal disease, likely represents a hyperdense
   cyst, although underlying tumor cannot be ruled out. Close followup
   with ultrasound is recommended. Two left renal cysts as detailed above,
   (2, 29), (2, 21).
   -will need f/u as outpt
   .
   #. FEN: tube feeds on. Needs S+S eval.  IVF boluses for hypotension.
   Will continue to follow electrolytes and replete as necessary.  Renal
   also following with CVVH protocol- will have to be sure that he can
   still get it now that filter clotted off.

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with a three-day history of malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- He is awake and alert but non-verbal.
- He has good air movement in bilateral anterior lung fields and clear to auscultation.
- He has distant heart sounds with no audible murmurs.
- His abdomen is soft, non-tender, non-distended, and positive for bowel sounds (BS).
- He has trace pedal edema.

The patient's laboratory results show:
- Hemoglobin (Hb): 6.4 g/dL
- Hematocrit (Hct): 21.8%
- White Blood Cell Count (WBC): 14.5
- Platelet Count (Plt): 704
- Creatinine (Cr): 4.2 mg/dL
- Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN): 101 mEq/L
- Glucose: 154 mg/dL
- Sodium (Na+): 139 mEq

Potential Medical Complications:

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection after a seizure and continues to have copious purulent secretions. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is planned to evaluate for vegetations.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to persistent infection and lung abscesses. Pressors have been discontinued.
4. Back Pain: The patient has ongoing back pain, which may be related to the lung abscesses. A clear collar is in place due to altered mental status, and further evaluation of the spine is needed.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.
- The patient is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure, acute, due to a lung abscess. He is also experiencing hypotension, anemia, seizure, pain control, and ESRD.
- He has a history of multiple blood cultures positive for MSSA and a tunneled catheter line suspected as the source of infection. He underwent a C/T/L spine CT with contrast, which showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses.
- His renal function is being monitored closely, and he is currently on hemodialysis (HD) with a negative recent HD session.
- The patient's back pain has been documented, and he has been given fentanyl for pain control.
- He has had an episode of tachypnea/presumed pain yesterday and received a bolus of fentanyl.
- The patient's seizure was attributed to HD and oxcarbazepine. He is currently on levet

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis, likely secondary to the MSSA infection. There is suspicion that the tunnelled catheter line may be the source of infection. 2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection after a seizure. He continues to have copious purulent secretions overnight. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is planned to evaluate for vegetations. The patient was extubated, but still requires close monitoring.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to persistent infection and lung abscesses. He is now off pressors. There was an episode of hypotension overnight, which responded to a fluid bolus.
4. Back Pain: The patient has back pain, which may be related to the lung abscesses. He underwent a C/T/L Spine CT with

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, found down, and was initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for MSSA sepsis.

The patient has several medical complications including sepsis, respiratory failure, hypotension, anemia, and pain control. He is currently on dialysis and has a tunneled catheter line, which may be a potential source of infection. The patient also has lung abscesses and a history of seizures. His renal function is impaired, and he has a history of ileus. He also has a non-ischemic CMY and requires monitoring for fluid status and medication adjustments.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for further complications due to ongoing infection and possible septic shock. Close monitoring of vital signs, blood cultures, and antibiotic therapy is necessary.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient may experience difficulty weaning off mechanical ventilation due to the presence of lung abscesses and ongoing respiratory secretions. Tracheostomy and airway protection may be considered.
3. Hypotension: Persistent hypotension may occur due to persistent infection

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presents with MSSA bacteremia and sepsis, for which he is being treated with nafcillin. The patient also has hypotension, which is being managed with fluid boluses and packed red blood cells (pRBCs) transfusion. He is experiencing delirium, respiratory failure, and pain control issues. Additionally, he has impaired skin integrity, renal failure, and sepsis without organ dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening of the patient's septic state, further deterioration in renal function, development of pressure ulcers due to impaired skin integrity, and potential complications related to dialysis.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, particularly blood pressure and heart rate, and ensure adequate fluid resuscitation. Frequent assessment of renal function parameters, such as serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), should be performed to evaluate the progression of renal failure. Regular turning and assessment of the skin integrity are crucial to prevent pressure ulcers. Additionally, close monitoring of the patient's mental status is necessary to assess for any changes in delirium.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for MSSA sepsis. The patient is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, hypotension (not shock), and pain control. He has undergone multiple interventions and treatments.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is currently in sepsis, likely due to a tunnelled catheter line infection. Blood cultures are pending, but earlier cultures grew MSSA. The source of infection needs to be identified and treated appropriately.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection after a seizure and continues to have copious purulent secretions. He has mild respiratory acidosis on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and was switched to assisted control (AC) overnight with slight improvement. Extubation may be considered if the patient's condition improves.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to persistent infection and lung abscesses. He is off pressors, but there was a hypotensive episode overnight that responded to a fluid bolus.

4. Anemia

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease, and a previous myocardial infarction. He presents with malaise, back pain, and was found down initially with hyperkalemia. The patient has been admitted multiple times with MSSA sepsis, pulmonary abscesses, and pseudomonas in a wound culture. He is currently hypotensive and febrile, suspected to be in sepsis. Blood cultures and line culture are pending, but earlier cultures grew MSSA. The patient is on nafcillin for MSSA and will have his temporary femoral dialysis catheter removed today, with plans for tunneled catheter placement tomorrow. He will undergo hemodialysis tomorrow morning. The patient also has anemia, respiratory failure, chronic pain, renal failure, altered mental status, and a renal mass. He is receiving various medications for pain control, infection, and management of his conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient is currently in sepsis, as indicated by hypotension, fever, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures for MSSA. The source of infection is suspected to be the tunneled catheter line. It is important to monitor blood pressure, follow cultures, and consider adding pseudomonas coverage if necessary.

Summary:
Summary:
- The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He presented with malaise, was found down, and had hyperkalemia. He was transferred from the floor due to methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.
- The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has been treated with nafcillin for MSSA. Despite this, he remains hypotensive and febrile. Blood cultures show MSSA and Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the wound culture from 8/31.
- The patient has altered mental status and is delirious, which could be due to sepsis or hypotension.
- He has anemia and received one unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs), with a hematocrit of 23.8% today. There is no evidence of active bleeding.
- The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to persistent infection and lung abscesses. He remains on levophed.
- The patient has back pain and underwent a C-spine CT with contrast, which showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses.
- The patient has ESRD and is currently on hemodialysis (HD) through a temporary line. He will receive HD today and then have the temporary line pulled.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and previous myocardial infarction (MI). He presented with malaise, was found down, and had hyperkalemia. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis. The patient has been hypotensive with fevers, suggesting ongoing sepsis. Cultures are pending, but earlier cultures grew MSSA. There is suspicion that the tunnelled catheter line may be the source of infection. 

The patient's current conditions include anemia, alteration in nutrition, impaired skin integrity, respiratory failure, acute pain, chronic pain, renal failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and back pain. 

Assessment and Plan:
1. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient is in sepsis with suspected source being the tunnelled catheter line. Blood cultures and line culture are pending. He is currently on nafcillin for MSSA and will continue to follow cultures. The hypotension is expected to improve after removing the line. 
2. Back Pain: The patient has full-body pain, specifically back pain. A C-spine was placed, and a CT scan with contrast showed no gross abscess but did show lung abscesses. 
3. ESRD: The patient is HD dependent

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, was found down, and had hyperkalemia with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.

The patient's current medical complications include sepsis without organ dysfunction, hypotension (not in shock), renal failure (ESRD), anemia, altered mental status (AMS), diffuse pain/weakness, ileus, non-ischemic CMY, and seizure disorder.

The patient's lab results show leukocytosis, elevated creatinine levels, hyperglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia. Imaging studies reveal lung abscesses, a sacral pustule, and a renal mass.

The patient's current treatment plan includes ongoing administration of antibiotics for MSSA sepsis, hemodialysis, pain management, seizure control, and management of anemia. The patient's blood cultures and line culture are pending, and there is a concern for possible empyema or pulmonary abscesses.

Overall, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications and ongoing management in the ICU.

The patient presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia and back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient is still hypotensive with fevers, likely due to MSSA bacteremia with pulmonary abscesses. There are pending blood cultures, and earlier cultures grew MSSA. The source of infection is suspected to be the tunneled catheter line.
- Anemia: The patient has a hematocrit (Hct) of 21.3%, indicating anemia. The cause of anemia could be chronic kidney disease or gastrointestinal bleeding, as indicated by a guaiac-positive stool of unknown etiology.
- Diffuse pain/weakness: The patient has diffuse pain and weakness, which is likely related to his underlying medical conditions.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis. 

The patient's current conditions include sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure (acute), anemia (other), alteration in nutrition, impaired skin integrity, seizure without status epilepticus, hypotension (not in shock), pain control (acute pain, chronic pain), renal failure (end-stage), and altered mental status.

The assessment and plan include:

1. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient is currently in sepsis with hypotension and fevers. The suspected source of infection is the tunneled catheter line. Blood cultures and line culture are pending, but earlier cultures grew MSSA. The patient is already on nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia with pulmonary abscesses. Cultures will be continued to be followed.

2. Anemia: The patient has a Hct of 21.3% and a guaiac positive stool of unknown etiology

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He presented to the hospital with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis. The patient is currently on hemodialysis (HD) and has several comorbidities including anemia, altered mental status, pain control, respiratory failure, seizure, hypotension, renal failure, and sepsis without organ dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient is currently in sepsis, which is suspected to be related to the tunneled catheter line. Despite being on nafcillin, he remains hypotensive with fevers. Blood cultures are pending, but earlier cultures grew MSSA. The source of infection appears to be the tunnelled catheter line, and the patient's hypotension and fevers are expected to improve once the line is removed and replaced.

2. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 21.8% today, with a previous transfusion of 1 unit packed red blood cells (PRBC) yesterday. He has a guaiac positive stool of unknown

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) presenting with diffuse pain, weakness, altered mental status, and hypotension. The patient has been admitted multiple times for MSSA sepsis, pulmonary abscesses, and other comorbidities. He is currently on dialysis and has been experiencing persistent diffuse pain and weakness. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he continues to have fevers and an elevated white blood cell count. Imaging shows no evidence of acute hemorrhage or vascular territorial infarction in the brain, but there is an interval increase in the opacification of bilateral maxillary sinuses and frontal opacification, which could be related to the patient's intubated status. The patient has a history of seizures and is currently on antiepileptic medication. He also has anemia, renal failure, and a possible renal mass that needs to be followed up with ultrasound. The patient's pain and weakness remain uncontrolled despite medication adjustments. Fluid overload is present, and the patient is still hypotensive. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis without organ dysfunction: The patient has been previously treated for MSSA sepsis with pulmonary abscesses, and there are ongoing signs of infection indicated by fevers and leukocytosis. The source of the

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. He was admitted to the floor for suspected MSSA sepsis but was later transferred to the ICU due to hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures for MSSA bacteremia with pulmonary abscesses. The source of infection is suspected to be a tunneled catheter line. He is currently on nafcillin and will be switched to cefazolin when on regular dialysis. 

The patient has several medical complications, including anemia, altered mental status, respiratory failure, acute pain, renal failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and a possible renal mass. His pain and weakness are attributed to a cervical spine condition, and he has a history of seizure disorder. 

His vital signs include a temperature of 37.9°C, blood pressure ranging from 92/42 mmHg to 117/66 mmHg, heart rate between 91-102 bpm, respiratory rate of 12-21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and liver enzymes. Blood cultures are pending, and imaging studies reveal decreasing pulmonary abscesses and pleural effusions.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%). He presented with malaise, was found down, and initially had hyperkalemia with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.

Current assessment:
- The patient is currently in sepsis but afebrile for 24 hours.
- He has hypotension and leukocytosis with positive blood cultures for MSSA.
- The source of infection is suspected to be a tunneled catheter line.
- He has several blood cultures and line culture pending.
- His pulmonary abscesses are decreasing in size.
- He has pleural effusions obscuring the lower lungs.
- No vegetations were seen on repeat trans-thoracic echocardiogram (TTE).
- He has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.5 g/dL.
- He has been receiving dialysis and will likely go to rehabilitation after ICU stay.
- He has diffuse pain and weakness.
- He has a history of seizure disorder.
- He has a temporary dialysis line and no plans to place a tunneled catheter since he is still febrile.
- He has an enlarged thyroid, which will be followed up

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (CMY) with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. The patient was admitted with a 3-day history of malaise, found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. He was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis.

The patient's current condition includes intermittent fevers, persistent pulmonary abscesses, and a suspected source as a tunneled hemodialysis (HD) catheter line. He is off pressors and remains normotensive. The patient's blood cultures were positive for MSSA, and he has been on nafcillin for 16 days out of a total of 42 days. The chest CT from September 9th demonstrates mildly improving infection.

The patient's medical history also includes a myocardial infarction (MI) and severe hypokinesis/near akinesis of the basal to mid-septal, anterior, and inferior segments of the left ventricle. He has been prescribed medications such as digoxin, fentanyl patch, morphine, gabapentin, levetiracetam, and oxcarbazepine.

The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is currently on maintenance hemodialysis

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a history of myocardial infarction (MI). He was admitted with a three-day history of malaise, found down, and initially hyperkalemic with back pain. The patient was transferred from the floor for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) sepsis. 

During his stay in the ICU, the patient's condition has been fluctuating. He presented with initial hypotension, hypoglycemia, leukocytosis, positive blood culture for MSSA, and a pulmonary abscess on chest CT, which is suspected to be the source as the tunneled hemodialysis (HD) catheter line. The patient remains normotensive, off pressors, with intermittent fevers, and his pulmonary infection appears to be mildly improving. 

The patient is currently on nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia with pulmonary abscesses and will transition to cefazolin for easier dosing at the rehabilitation facility per Infectious Disease (ID) recommendation. Surveillance cultures will continue until the patient becomes afebrile.

Other barriers to rehabilitation include persistent difficulties with nasogastric tube (NGT) feeding, including a recently placed Dobhoff tube, raising the question of percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG). The patient will require a permanent tun
